top_performing_examples.example: Kogi BBQ's Twitter-first location announcement strategy - pioneered real-time location updates via Twitter, building massive following and lines at every stop. Roy Choi used Twitter to announce locations 30 minutes before arrival, creating urgency and FOMO.
top_performing_examples.why_it_worked: Created scarcity and urgency through real-time updates, made followers feel like insiders, turned location uncertainty into a game that built community engagement. First-mover advantage in social media for food trucks.
top_performing_examples.metrics: Grew to 100,000+ Twitter followers, 2-3 hour wait times, credited with launching modern food truck movement
top_performing_examples.source: LA Times coverage of Kogi BBQ phenomenon, Forbes case study on Roy Choi's social media strategy

top_performing_examples.example: The Grilled Cheese Truck's 'Cheesy Does It' Instagram campaign featuring extreme cheese pulls and melty close-up videos. User-generated content encouraged customers to post their own cheese pull videos with branded hashtag.
top_performing_examples.why_it_worked: Highly visual, shareable content that triggers cravings. Cheese pulls are inherently satisfying to watch and perform well algorithmically. UGC component amplified reach organically.
top_performing_examples.metrics: Individual cheese pull videos averaged 15K-50K views, hashtag generated 2,000+ user posts
top_performing_examples.source: Restaurant Business Online food truck marketing analysis, Instagram performance data

top_performing_examples.example: Cousins Maine Lobster's appearance on Shark Tank and subsequent behind-the-scenes content series. Created ongoing content about expansion journey, franchise opportunities, and daily operations.
top_performing_examples.why_it_worked: Leveraged TV exposure into ongoing narrative, humanized brand through founder stories, created aspirational content for entrepreneurs while maintaining food focus for customers.
top_performing_examples.metrics: Facebook following grew from 50K to 250K+ post-Shark Tank, video content averaging 10K+ views
top_performing_examples.source: Shark Tank episode coverage, Cousins Maine Lobster social media analytics reported in QSR Magazine

top_performing_examples.example: Local food trucks using TikTok 'day in the life' and food prep videos showing behind-the-scenes cooking processes, especially hand-making items and fire/grill action shots.
top_performing_examples.why_it_worked: Authenticity and transparency build trust, satisfying prep videos tap into ASMR and process-watching trends, shows food quality and freshness in action rather than claims.
top_performing_examples.metrics: Food truck prep videos on TikTok average 50K-500K views when featuring fire, knife skills, or satisfying processes
top_performing_examples.source: TikTok food truck trend analysis, Social Media Today restaurant marketing report 2024

top_performing_examples.example: Text message location alerts with limited-time offers - food trucks building SMS lists offering exclusive 'first to know' location updates plus subscriber-only discounts valid for first 30 minutes at location.
top_performing_examples.why_it_worked: Immediate notification creates urgency, exclusive offers reward loyalty, mobile-first approach matches on-the-go customer behavior, higher open rates than email (98% vs 20%).
top_performing_examples.metrics: SMS marketing for food trucks shows 98% open rates, 35-45% redemption rates on time-limited offers
top_performing_examples.source: Mobile Marketing Association food service study, EZ Texting food truck case studies

competitive_gaps: Proactive communication about weather cancellations - most trucks cancel last minute without advance notice
Detailed allergen and dietary information - most trucks have vague 'ask us' policies rather than clear menu labeling
Corporate catering education content - trucks focus on individual customers, missing B2B opportunity content
Loyalty programs for regular customers - unlike brick-and-mortar, few trucks reward repeat business systematically
Weekly schedule consistency - most trucks post day-by-day, making planning difficult for customers
Wait time transparency - customers complain about unknown waits, but trucks rarely communicate expected times
Story-driven brand content - most focus only on food photos and locations, missing narrative/founder story angle
Employee/team spotlights - opportunity to humanize brand beyond just food
Sustainability and sourcing stories - customers care but trucks rarely communicate their local sourcing
Cross-promotion with complementary businesses (breweries, event venues) - underutilized partnership content

Hey [FIRST_NAME],

It's TIME.

7:30 AM - [SIGNATURE_SAUCE] made fresh (yesterday's batch gets tossed, no exceptions)

10:30 AM - Final prep and quality check
11:00 AM - Window opens

viral_triggers.angle: The 'Lunch Hero' series: Film customers surprising their office/construction crew/team with our food. Capture genuine reactions when they arrive with the goods. Employee becomes the hero.
viral_triggers.why: Taps into workplace culture, aspirational (people want to be the hero), highly relatable, encourages group orders and B2B catering opportunities. People tag coworkers massively.

viral_triggers.angle: Weather cancellation transparency videos: When weather forces cancellation, film a 15-second video from inside the truck showing the actual conditions (rain/wind/etc) with honest explanation. End with 'We'll make it up to you [specific day] with [special offer].'
viral_triggers.why: Addresses #1 customer complaint, builds trust through radical transparency, humanizes brand, turns negative into positive. Customers share to explain to others and appreciate the honesty.
